channel.title: Changing .Class files
channel.description:
Hey guys i have a source and cannot figure out how to make this source run off of other clients... this source only runs off a certain client... i figured it could possibly be in .class files?
Help me out guys... ;D
Thanks, Adam

item.title: Changing .Class files
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

[quote=“upto45, post:1, topic:354823”]Hey guys i have a source and cannot figure out how to make this source run off of other clients… this source only runs off a certain client… i figured it could possibly be in .class files?

Help me out guys… ;D

Thanks,
Adam[/quote]

[i]In the Java programming language, source files (.java files) are compiled into (virtual) machine-readable class files which have a .class extension. Since Java is a platform-independent language, source code is compiled into an output file known as bytecode, which it stores in a .class file. If a source file has more than one class, each class is compiled into a separate .class file. These .class files can be loaded by any Java Virtual Machine (JVM).

Since JVMs are available for many platforms, the .class file compiled in one platform will execute in a JVM of another platform. This makes Java platform-independent.[/i]

You should only edit the Java source files, although you CAN edit .class files it is not advised, one way you can edit a .class file is by decompiling it into a Java source code file, but as you have the source code, there is no need.

Just a message so you know what a .class file actually… Just for knowledge.

Read full topic
